description: From Middle English institucioun, from Old French institution, from Latin institūtiō, from instituō (“to set up”), from in- (“in, on”) + statuō (“to set up, establish”).

entries.meaning: A custom or practice of a society or community.
examples: The institution of marriage is present in many cultures but its details vary widely across them.

entries.meaning: A  long established and respected organization, particularly one involved with education, public service, or charity work.
examples: The University of the South Pacific is the only internationally accredited institution of higher education in Oceania.

entries.meaning: The building or buildings which house such an organization.
examples: He's been in an institution since the crash.

entries.meaning: (informal) Any long established and respected place or business.
examples: Over time, the local pub has become something of an institution.

entries.meaning: (informal) A person long established in a place, position, or field.
examples: She's not just any old scholar; she is an institution.
The institution of higher speed limits was a popular move but increased the severity of crashes.

entries.meaning: (Christianity) The act by which a bishop commits a cure of souls to a priest.
(obsolete) That which institutes or instructs, particularly a textbook or system of elements or rules.
